Given that force, momentum, energy, etc. are abstractions, I wonder whether much (or at least part) of the issue is conceptual and semi-semantic. Physics has very precise definitions of those concepts, but most people use fuzzier approximations. Someone untrained in that precision may say something like “the force eventually peters out” whereas a physicist would say “the momentum decreases as the ball slows due to air resistance and friction when the ball bounces”. And rather than saying there’s a “force in the ball” we’d call that kinetic energy.

Experientially when the ball is coming at you and you grab it with your arms your experience a force. Although less precise (and in some sense incorrect) to say that a force is in the ball, I doubt very much that instead calling it kinetic energy will do much to improve a player’s ability to play basketball well.

In short: are the questions testing understanding or are they mostly testing for the formalisms of physics. If we’re teaching physics to begin with, why do folks score so low in the test before watching the video? It makes perfect sense in the context of system 1 (fast/intuitive) and system 2 (slow/analytical) thinking. In other experiments it is found that when reading something, people will engage system 2 (and catch more errors or learn more from it) when it's written in a more difficult to read font. Same with any situation where you trip people up, they will switch modes. In my experience, normal people do not like using system 2 and they seem to actively avoid it whenever possible. Meanwhile science requires system 2... our intuitions about the way many things work are wrong, which is why science is even necessary in the first place. (If our intuitions were correct, there would be no such word or concept as "science.") In fact you could describe the scientific method as a set of steps which eliminate system 1 from the thought process.

So another way to see this is that the key to teaching science effectively is finding ways to get people to engage system 2 (and keep it engaged) which most people will find boring, annoying, tedious, confusing, etc, as your research showed.

+Veritasium I think there is a simple solution to this. Do not conceive of Khan Academy as a the whole package, but have that as a part of the process. We do have traditional assessment questions, (recognizing whether a statement is true or false - verifying the veracity :D - matching assertions with reasons, being able to answer questions in a word, or a perfect sentence, interacting with graphics and diagrams). These exercises, along with peer review, will be able to get students to bring their preconceived notions to the fore. After the students have built an awareness of their understanding, they can start modifying it, until we take the students to a point where they can correct their own thinking.

Edit: And oh yes, the other thing is that expecting students to learn a given concept and making them learn few specific points and skills rightaway is very difficult. Whatever new information is presented to them is in the end, a bunch of neural activity. Until the day that the neural activity is consolidated, recalled regularly and then allowed to be modified/applied, the learning won't be effective. It won't be any learning at all!

Putting it differently, it would be amazing if we conceptualized learning through digital resources as a progression through "Bloom's Taxonomy" of tasks, and allow students to progress freely through that level.

The ball starts from a greater height than it lands at, so the pull on it is decreasing for less time than it is increasing.
So I think it's less confusing to think of the force as constant.
